snippet: Federal regulators filed a discrimination lawsuit yesterday on behalf of three female construction workers who claimed that they were sexually harassed and forced to pick up after their male colleagues while working at a job site in Brooklyn. The ...
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators filed a discrimination lawsuit yesterday on behalf of three female construction workers who claimed that they were sexually harassed and forced to pick up after their male colleagues while working at a job site in Brooklyn. The three women complained last year to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission that they were subjected to a hostile work environment while working for Tratoros Construction Inc., a general contractor hired by the New York Housing Authority to renovate the Williamsburg Houses in northern Brooklyn. After investigating their claims, the commission filed a sexual discrimination suit on their behalf in United States District Court in Brooklyn. In its formal complaint, the commission said, ''Offensive and unwelcome comments were made regarding women's menstruation and sexual activity.'' The complaint accuses one of the company's male supervisors of telling his male colleagues to leave the women alone ''because they had cramps'' and ordered the women to ''change their Pampers.'' The supervisor also asked the women if they had recently had sex and publicly accused two of them of having an affair, according to the complaint. The three women say they were forced to clean bathrooms and kitchens and wash windows while the men did demolition and paint jobs. Chris Curis, a spokesman for Tratoros, said the company denied all of the allegations and he could not discuss continuing litigation. Alan Feuer (NYT)
abstract: Federal regulators file discrimination lawsuit on behalf of three female construction workers who claim they were sexually harassed and forced to pick up after male colleagues while working for Tratoros Construction Inc at job site in Brooklyn (S)

snippet: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide the extent to which employers must provide medical coverage for the pregnancies of male employees' wives.   The question for the Court is the scope of a law Congress passed in 1978 to require employers to t...
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide the extent to which employers must provide medical coverage for the pregnancies of male employees' wives. The question for the Court is the scope of a law Congress passed in 1978 to require employers to treat ''women affected by pregnancy'' and related medical conditions ''the same for all employment-related purposes'' as ''other persons not so affected in their ability or inability to work.'' No one doubts that the law, the Pregnancy Discrimination Act, requires employers to give their employees the same coverage for the medical expenses of pregnancy as it provides for any other medical expenses.
